Award.AwardTitle: Core Support for the Institute for Laboratory Animal Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
The responsible and thoughtful care and use of animal in research, testing, training, and education is important from a moral and ethical point of view, as well as for the collection of high-quality, replicable data. The mission of ILAR is to identify, develop, promote, and disseminate strategies and practices that provide for excellence in the welfare of animals in academic or industry research, training, and education. This award serves to provide renewed support for core mechanisms through which ILAR accomplishes its mission. ILAR developed and continues to update the "Guide to the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals", a document that is the basis for governmental regulations on animal care and use in research and education, and that sets performances standards and best practices in animal care and use worldwide. ILAR also produces reports that provide the basis of guidelines and policy development for the care and use of animals in specific research domains. Further, ILAR oversees the content of the ILAR Journal, and ILAR is responsible for the ILAR Roundtable on Science and Welfare in Laboratory Animal Use, which organizes workshops on timely animal welfare-related issues of interest to research communities as well as government, industry, and professional societies, and whose outcomes ILAR disseminates worldwide. Additionally, through its role as a collaborating center for laboratory animal science and welfare of the World Animal Health Organization and an international fellowship training program, ILAR influences animal welfare awareness and best practices in laboratory animal medicine and science worldwide. ILAR operations are carried out by ILAR staff working under the oversight of ILAR Council, which includes representatives from academia, industry, biomedical and wildlife research, veterinarian medicine, and safety and regulatory affairs.

The specific ILAR activities supported through this award include the oversight of the ILAR Journal, ILAR Council meetings, and the development and dissemination of ILAR publications and on-line material resulting from the ILAR Roundtable workshops. Although the emphasis is on animals in laboratory research, ILAR has and continues to take steps to broaden its scope to include animals in wildlife as well as agricultural research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project entitled "Core Support for the Institute of Laboratory Animal Research" enabled the Institute (ILAR) to continue operations of its three pillars: The Institute's Laboratory Animal Research Council, Roundtable on the Science and Welfare of Laboratory Animal Use, and the ILAR Journal. These efforts serve government agencies, the scientific community, and the general public. The mission of ILAR is to evaluate and report on the scientific, technological, and ethical use of animals in research, testing, education, and production of pharmaceuticals and chemicals. ILAR staff work to identify science-based practices that provide for excellence in the welfare of research animals, while achieving high-quality science and evaluates and encourages the development, validation, and use of non-animal alternatives.

The Laboratory Animal Research Council has oversight responsibility for all ILAR activities. The Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals is ILAR's most influential product. Through adoption by the National Institutes of Health (NIH) under the Health Research Extension Act of 1985 (Public Law 99-158, November 20, 1985, "Animals in Research"), the Guide serves as the basis of the Public Health Service (PHS) Policy on Humane Care and Use of Laboratory Animals. All federally-funded animal research institutions and federal agencies conducting animal research must follow the Guide. The Guide is also used as a basis for accreditation by the Association for Assessment and Accreditation of Laboratory Animal Care (AAALAC) International, which provides accreditation to laboratory animal care and use facilities worldwide. Other ILAR reports have also made substantial contributions to the advancement of science and research, and the care, use and welfare of research animals.

The Roundtable on Science and Welfare in Laboratory Animal Use provides a forum to foster communication and problem solving among the different constituencies with strong interests in the use of animals in research. Roundtable members include representatives from the government, private corporations, professional societies, and academic institutions. The Roundtable convenes workshops to facilitate on-going discussion and information exchange on topics of interest to those involved with the science and welfare of using research animals.  The workshops are open to the public and webcasted, and there is no fee charged to attend live workshops or view them via the worldwide web. After the workshop takes place, slide presentations, session videos of panel discussions, and often, workshop proceedings, are posted on-line and made freely available to the public. 

The ILAR Journal is a unique publication on contemporary topics related to animal research. Three issues are published yearly, and each issue provides invited articles from experts on a themed topic. The Journal is available through subscriptions, and after a six-month embargo from the date of publication of the issue, journal articles are freely available for download without regard to subscriber status.

Addendum # 1

Studies on the Life Sciences require the use of animals in research for a wide variety of research activities. Although much animal research is carried out on specially bred rats, mice, guinea pigs, rabbits or primates as surrogates for humans in biomedical research, other animal-related studies and educational activities have importance for high-rewards in areas of critical national need.

There is a great deal of animal research that is directed at understanding the biology of animals per se and that is not concerned with human health. The growing need for these studies is toward understanding the earth’s biodiversity and investigating a wide range of diverse animal physiologies and behaviors to benefit the species under study. Many of these activities are being conducted in natural settings, for example on wildlife species in their natural habitats. Advances in technology, such high-throughput genetic sequencing, has contributed to increasingly more researchers moving away from using the traditional laboratory model species in brick and mortar facilities. Furthermore, the growing need for studies on wildlife and biodiversity conservation has led to an increase in in-situ biodiversity and wildlife studies that may require protocol review and approval by institutional animal care and use committees.

To have excellence in science, consistent with current scientific literature, it is also critical for both ethical and scientific reasons to concurrently have excellence in animal care and use when animals are a part of the research activity. Consistent with ILAR’s mission, this project began the process of ILAR including in its mission the use of wildlife and other animals in research outside traditional brick and mortar buildings. ILAR published 38 articles with relevance to these types of studies in the ILAR Journal. Two entire issues (Volume 56, Issue 3 and Volume 58, Issue 3) of the ILAR Journal were devoted to wildlife topics, including the incorporation of a commentary on Guidance for Field Biology and Other Studies on Wildlife Species by John C. Wingfield, former NSF Assistant Director for Biology, and the document entitled, Animal Welfare Policy: Implementation in the Context of Wildlife Research, in Volume 56, Issue 3. All publications of the ILAR Journal can be found and accessed free of charge by visiting:

http:// https://academic.oup.com/ilarjournal/pages/ilar_journal_issue_themes.

 Also, for this project, the ILAR Roundtable organized and convened four public globally-webcasted workshops on the following topics: 1) Animal Models for Microbiome Research: Advancing Basic and Translational Sciences; 2) Advancing Disease Modeling in Animals-Based Research in Support of Precision Medicine; 3) Care, Use and Welfare of Marmosets As Animal Models for Gene Editing-Based Biomedical Research; and 4) Human-Animal Interactions in the Research Environment.  Proceedings for these four workshops are freely available for download by searching for the workshop name on the National Academies Press website at http://nap.edu.

Additional outcomes of this project include: 1) ILAR expanding its advisory council membership to include five new members having field experience in wildlife and/or with the use of wildlife species in non-laboratory settings; 2) the new ILAR Council meeting in-person and engaging with an esteemed panel of NSF scientists about their research activities using wildlife and non-model species in natural settings: 3) a series of subsequent meetings for internal and external development efforts for ILAR to set forth new strategic initiatives to address animal welfare challenges in research and education on wildlife and non-model species, and to further identify ways to enhance the welfare of animals used for research in non-laboratory settings, further improve institutional-level animal research programs and oversight, and build additional capacity to inform the future development of activities to expand ILAR’s mission into the broader animal researcher stakeholder community.
